definition: rhyming word ending a line of verse/rhyme
the final (of a syllable) (Chinese phonology)/rhyme/appeal/charm/(literary) pleasant sound
foot/leg (of an animal or an object)/base (of an object)/CL:雙|双[shuang1],隻|只[zhi1]/classifier for kicks
variant of 角[jue2]/role

sentences.english: The level tone feet of the metrical verse embodies the harmony of parole of language.
sentences.chinese: 平声韵脚充分体现出了言语与语言之间的和谐互动。

sentences.english: It helps them memorize the months with a catchy rhyme.
sentences.chinese: 它以朗朗上口的韵脚来帮助他们记起月份。

sentences.english: The grade two student's rhythm awareness is better than their phonemic awareness.
sentences.chinese: 初中二年级学生的英语韵脚意识的发展好于音位意识。

sentences.english: Once published , his work became famous for the absence of rhyme at the end of each line.
sentences.chinese: 他的书一出版，就因为每行末缺乏韵脚而闻名。

definition: level and oblique tones (technical term for Classical Chinese rhythmic poetry)
to rhyme/sometimes written 壓韻|压韵
forms of versification/conventions regarding set number of words and lines, choice of tonal patterns and rhyme schemes for various types of Classical Chinese poetic composition/metrical verse
syntax
antithesis (two lines of poetry matching in sense and sound)/to fight/to wage war
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
foot (syllabic unit in verse)/meter/scansion
a genre of poetry, developed in the Tang Dynasty, characterized by its strict form
names of the tunes to which 詞|词[ci2] poems are composed
variant of 押韻|押韵[ya1 yun4]
poetic form or genre
oblique tone/nonlevel tone/uneven tone (the third tone of Classical Chinese)
number of sentences/number of lines (in verse etc)
cadence/rhythm/rhyme scheme/meter (in verse)/(linguistics) prosody
change of rhyme (within a poem)
words and sentences
